Ethnic slurs.description: List of ethnic slurs according to wiki with description. Contains several normally harmless terms. I've left them, because some moderators *will* upload this stuff uncritically to their filter and badly designed MR algorithm might still react. Add it to be aware that there might be a reaction.

terms.description:
Location or origin: United States, Canada
Targets: Jewish men
Meaning, origin and notes: Originated before the 1950s. From the proper name Abraham.

Location or origin: East Asia
Targets: American-born Chinese, Han or other Chinese (including Taiwanese) born and raised in the United States.
Meaning, origin and notes: The term implies an otherness or lack of connection to their Chinese identity and (usually) Chinese language; however, it has been reappropriated by many Chinese Americans and used to convey positive connotations.

Location or origin: South Asians in the US
Targets: American-Born Confused Desi, Indian Americans or other South Asian Americans, (desi) who were born in the United States.
Meaning, origin and notes: Used chiefly by South Asian immigrants to imply confusion about cultural identity

Location or origin: Middle East and North Africa
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Arabic for slave, associated with the Arab slave trade

Location or origin: Australia
Targets: Australian Aboriginal person
Meaning, origin and notes: Originally, this was simply an informal term for Aborigine, and was in fact used by Aboriginal people themselves (such as in the Aboriginal-run newspaper Abo Call) until it started to be considered offensive in the 1950s. Although Abo is still considered quite offensive by many, the pejorative boong is now more commonly used when the intent is deliberately to offend, as that word's status as an insult is unequivocal.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: African Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: Shoddy, second-rate or unconventional, makeshift workmanship. Indirectly refers to black American people as worse or lower-valued than white American people when associating anything bad with them.

Location or origin: Hong Kong
Targets: South Asian people
Meaning, origin and notes: From 阿差; Cantonese Yale: achā; from "acchā" meaning "good" or "OK" in Hindi.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Iraqi people
Meaning, origin and notes: An Iraqi suspected of criminal activity.

Location or origin: United States (chiefly southern U.S.)
Targets: Black people, especially black children
Meaning, origin and notes: Dates from early 20th century or before; implies that African Americans are good for nothing except being used to bait alligators

Location or origin: Serbo-Croatian: Alpski Srbin (ex-Yugoslavia)
Targets: People of Slovenian origin.
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: Khoisans and Cape Coloureds or Coloureds
Meaning, origin and notes: Xhosa words for Hottentot

Location or origin: Malaysia, Singapore
Targets: European people, especially the Dutch
Meaning, origin and notes: Hokkien for "red hair" referring to Dutch people from the 17th century and expanded to encompass other Europeans by the 19th century. It has become a neutral term, though is sometimes seen as derogatory.

Location or origin: United States, Canada
Targets: White women, "white-acting" black women
Meaning, origin and notes: While Miss Ann, also just plain Ann, is a derisive reference to white women, it is also applied to any black woman who is deemed to be acting as though she is white.

Location or origin: French, English
Targets: Vietnamese people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Referring to outdated theories ascribing cultural differences between racial groups as being linked to their evolutionary distance from chimpanzees, with which humans share common ancestry.

Location or origin: United States, Canada
Targets: Native Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: First used in the 1970s. Someone who is "red on the outside, white on the inside". Used primarily by other Native Americans to indicate someone who has lost touch with their cultural identity.

Location or origin: Israel
Targets: Arabs
Meaning, origin and notes: Arabs, derived from Hebrew "Aravi" (Arab).

Location or origin: United Kingdom
Targets: Argentine people
Meaning, origin and notes: Extensively used by the British soldiers during the Falklands War in 1982.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Armenian/Armenian American
Meaning, origin and notes: Especially used in Southern California.

Location or origin: Indonesia
Targets: Non-Indonesian people, especially Chinese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Insult to non-Indonesian citizen, from "[orang] asing" (foreigner) that rhymed with "Aseng" (Chinese name). This word is often directed at Chinese people due to Indonesia's relationship with the PRC.

Location or origin: Israel
Targets: Ashkenazi Jews
Meaning, origin and notes: Pronounced like "AshkeNatzi". Used mostly by Mizrachi Jews.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black women
Meaning, origin and notes: A black woman who "kisses up" to whites, a "sellout", female counterpart of Uncle Tom.

Location or origin: Ireland
Targets: Dublin people
Meaning, origin and notes: Believed to be in reference to the Union Jack, the flag of the United Kingdom. By adding the Irish diminutive suffix -een meaning little to Jack thereby ¨meaning "Little Jack" and implying "little Englishmen". It was more commonly used to separate those of Anglo-Irish heritage from those of Gaelic heritage. While the term is applied to Dublin people alone; today, it was applied in the past as a pejorative term against all city dwellers and not just those in Dublin.

Location or origin: Malaysia
Targets: Unsophisticated people, from the Malay name of an indigenous ethnic group.
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Indonesia
Targets: Javanese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Jamet stands for Jawa metal (a metalhead Javanese), while kuproy stands for kuli proyek (construction workers).

Location or origin: Brazil
Targets: Japanese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Usually an affectionate way of referring to Japanese people (or, more generally, East Asian people), although it may be considered a slur. This term is never censored (as a slur typically would be) when it appears in mass media.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Japanese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Mostly found use during World War II, post-WWII.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Jewish women
Meaning, origin and notes: Usually written in all capital letters as an acronym for "Jewish-American princess," a stereotype of certain Jewish American females as materialistic or pampered.

Location or origin: 
Targets: White, rural South Africans
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from plaasjapie, "farm boy".

Location or origin: Somalia
Targets: Somali bantus, Bantu Africans in general
Meaning, origin and notes: References the kinky hair of Bantu-speaking Africans which is less common among Somalis.

Location or origin: Indonesia
Targets: Javanese people, especially Javanese people with darker skin
Meaning, origin and notes: Comes from the words "Jawa" and "Ireng" from a Javanese word means black

Location or origin: Commonwealth
Targets: German people, especially soldiers
Meaning, origin and notes: Probably an alteration of "German". Origin of Jerry can. Used especially during World War I and World War II.

Location or origin: United States, United Kingdom
Targets: Jewish boys
Meaning, origin and notes: Originally directed at young Jewish boys who sold counterfeit coins in 18th century London.

Location or origin: Romania
Targets: Jewish person.
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black people with stereotypical black features (e.g., dark skin, wide nose, and big lips).
Meaning, origin and notes: From a Bantu verb tshikabo, meaning "they bow the head docilely," indicating meek or servile individuals.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Korea
Targets: Chinese people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Korea
Targets: Japanese people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: United Kingdom
Targets: Scottish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Scots language nickname for the personal name John, cognate to the English, Jack. Occasionally used as an insult, but also in a respectful reference when discussing Scottish troops, particularly those from Highland regiments. For example, see the 9th (Scottish) Division. Same vein as the English insult for the French, as Frogs. In Ian Rankin's detective novel Tooth and Nail the protagonist – a Scottish detective loaned to the London police – suffers from prejudice by English colleagues who frequently use "Jock" and "Jockland" (Scotland) as terms of insult; the book was based on the author's own experience as a Scot living in London.

Location or origin: United States, Commonwealth
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Finland
Targets: Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Northeastern Thailand
Targets: Vietnamese people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Arabian Peninsula, Muslims worldwide
Targets: Non-Muslims (regardless of race).
Meaning, origin and notes: Also caffer or caffre. from Arabic kafir meaning "disbeliever".

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: Black and Cape Coloured or Coloured people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: 
Targets: Members of a people inhabiting the Hindu Kush mountains of north-east Afghanistan
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: Black and Cape Coloured sympathizers during apartheid
Meaning, origin and notes: Meaning "Kaffir brothers", it is analogous to "negro lover" in English. The term is outdated and no longer used.

Location or origin: Burmese
Targets: Muslim citizens who are "black-skinned" or "undesirable aliens."
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Russian
Targets: Central Asians
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Hindi
Targets: Darkskinned people
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally means blackie generally used for black-skinned people in India, can also have racist overtone when referring to Africans.

Location or origin: Hindi
Targets: Muslim males
Meaning, origin and notes: Word used to describe Muslim males for having a circumicised penis as mentioned in the Khitan of Islam.

Location or origin: Australia
Targets: Pacific Islanders
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: German
Targets: Turkish people, foreigners in general
Meaning, origin and notes: Originally used to refer to Native Polynesians. To some extent re-appropriated.

Location or origin: Philippines
Targets: White Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: Usually used in Filipino (Tagalog) or other Philippine languages. Shortened from the Filipino word "Amerikano". It usually refers to Americans, especially a stereotypical male white American, which may extend to western foreigners that may fit the stereotype which the speaker is not familiar with, especially those from Europe, Australia, New Zealand, etc.

Location or origin: Canadian French
Targets: Native Americans
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Germany
Targets: Dutch people
Meaning, origin and notes: Middle German slur that translates to "cheese head".

Location or origin: Ukraine, Belarus, Poland, Lithuania, Russia
Targets: Russian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Ukrainian: кацап, Lithuanian: kacapas; self-deprecating usage by Russians.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Muslims, usually of Arabian or Turkic descent.
Meaning, origin and notes: Its origin is a Serbian music video that was recorded in 1993 during the Yugoslav Wars but the phrase has spread globally amongst far-right groups and the alt-right as a meme between 2006 and 2008. Famously Turkish internet users parodied the sentiment of Serbian nationalists online, with a satirical incoherent rant that ended with the phrase "remove kebab" being repeated. Although the meme initially intended to parody racism, this meaning behind the meme was lost once it became common in alt-right discourse.

Location or origin: Turkey
Targets: Kurdish men
Meaning, origin and notes: Originally neutral Kurdish word meaning man, pal, or friend, but became derogatory among Turkish speakers.

Location or origin: Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore
Targets: Indian people
Meaning, origin and notes: In Indonesian, the term can be applied to any person with dark complexion, not only of Indian descent, but also to native Indonesians with darker complexion and Africans. The term is derived from the ancient Indian region of Kalinga, where many immigrants to countries further east originated.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Native Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: The term used by the fictional Native American sidekick Tonto as the "Native American" name for the Lone Ranger in the American television and radio programs The Lone Ranger.

Location or origin: Japan
Targets: Westerners
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally means "foreigners full of body hair". Alternative form: ketōjin (毛唐人)

Location or origin: Russia
Targets: Peoples of the Caucasus, particularly North Caucasus and Armenians
Meaning, origin and notes: From Armenian խաչ khach, meaning cross (cf. khachkar). Khatchik is also an Armenian given name coming from the same root.

Location or origin: India
Targets: Assamese people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Russia
Targets: Ukrainian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from a term for a traditional Cossack-style haircut.

Location or origin: Vietnam
Targets: Chinese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Variant form of "Tàu khựa"

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: A person or people Indian heritage.
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Ashkenazi Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Possibly from קײַקל kikel, Yiddish for "circle". Immigrant Jews who could not read English often signed legal documents with an "O" (similar to an "X", to which Jews objected because "X" also symbolizes a cross).

Location or origin: 
Targets: Korean people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Turkey
Targets: Kurdish men
Meaning, origin and notes: A word used to describe rude and hairy men, pejoratively refers to the Kurds.

Location or origin: Russia
Targets: East Asian people, especially the Chinese.
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from "kitayets". (Cyrillic: китаец)

Location or origin: Ireland
Targets: Irish Travelers
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: South Korea
Targets: Westerners
Meaning, origin and notes: From 코 ("nose") and -쟁이 (derogatory suffix), prevalently used during the 19th and 20th centuries to refer to Caucasian foreigners

Location or origin: Ukraine
Targets: Pro-Russian separatists and Russian invaders
Meaning, origin and notes: In reference to Russian St. George ribbon whose coloration resembles the stripes of the Colorado beetle.

Location or origin: England
Targets: Scottish people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Denmark
Targets: Arabs, Middle Easterns
Meaning, origin and notes: While originally being used against greenlanders, it is now mostly used against Middel Easterns and Arabs. The word comes from the greenlandic word "Qaqqamut" meaning "to the mountain, up the mountain", however, the danish people began to pick up the word as an aggressive slur, and used it against the greenlanders, and slowly, it became a slur against the more frequent Arab and Middle Eastern immigrants in Denmark.

Location or origin: United States, Canada, Commonwealth
Targets: German people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from sauerkraut, used most specifically during World War II.

Location or origin: New Zealand
Targets: Māori people
Meaning, origin and notes: Term used to describe Māori people who cooperate with or who are subservient to white authority figures (similar to "Uncle Tom" qv). From historical Māori troops who sided with the colonial government in the 19th century.

Location or origin: Japan
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: A derogatory that literally means "darkie" or "nigga" in Japanese. The term has been used as a racial slur against black people, particularly during Japan's colonial era.

Location or origin: South Korea
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Korean for nigga or nigger.

Location or origin: Russia
Targets: Latvian and Lithuanian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from greetings: Latvian labrīt/labdien/labvakar and Lithuanian labas rytas/laba diena/labas vakaras, meaning "good morning/day/evening".

Location or origin: China
Targets: Foreigners
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally means "old foreign", less derogatory nowadays.

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: White South Africans
Meaning, origin and notes: The term implies that white people stole land from black people during the Apartheid era, and are therefore responsible for the current economic and social inequalities in the country.

Location or origin: Scandinavia
Targets: Sámi people
Meaning, origin and notes: Used mainly by Norwegians and Swedes. The word itself means "patch." "Lapland", considered non-offensive, refers to Sámi territory known as "Sápmi", Finland's northernmost county, or the province in northernmost Sweden.

Location or origin: Australia
Targets: A Lebanese person, usually a Lebanese Australian.
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Chile
Targets: German people
Meaning, origin and notes: Used by some Huilliche people of southern Chile. Means "toasted heads" in reference to the fair hair of many Germans. Originated during the German colonization of Valdivia, Osorno and Llanquihue in the mid 19th-century.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: British people
Meaning, origin and notes: Comes from the historical British naval practice of giving sailors limes to stave off scurvy.

Location or origin: Hong Kong
Targets: Mainland Chinese people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Indonesia
Targets: White people
Meaning, origin and notes: Commonly used by Javanese people. Derived from "Belanda" (Netherlands).

Location or origin: Likely derived from a Tasmanian Aboriginal language.
Targets: Australian Aboriginal Women
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Northern Ireland
Targets: Irish People
Meaning, origin and notes: A unionist that sympathies with Nationalists in Northern Ireland. The name emanates from Robert Lundy, a former Governor of Londonderry during the Siege of Derry in 1688, who is reviled as being a traitor to protestants and as such, an effigy of him is burned each year.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Lithuanian people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Ukraine, Russia
Targets: Polish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Lach is a term that originally referred to a representative of Slav tribes living roughly in what is today eastern Poland and western Ukraine, more commonly known today as Lendians, but later became associated with all Polish tribes. In other languages, Lach and derived expressions are neutral.

Location or origin: Zimbabwe
Targets: Local European people held in contempt, commonly white Africans of European ancestry.
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Europe
Targets: African people
Meaning, origin and notes: Originally used by francophone colonists in North Africa, also used in Europe against Immigrants from Africa.

Location or origin: Romania
Targets: Italian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Roughly means "macaroni eater/maker".

Location or origin: Arab world
Targets: Persian people
Meaning, origin and notes: A term meaning Zoroastrian, Magi, fire worshipper.

Location or origin: Iran
Targets: Arab people
Meaning, origin and notes: Meaning "locust eater," referring to the eating of locusts in Arab cuisine.

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: Khoisans and Cape Coloureds or Coloureds
Meaning, origin and notes: A derogatory Afrikaans slang word derived from Xhosa, used to insult coloured people and Khoisans by suggesting they lack cultural and racial roots and are therefore uncivilized. Its origin can be traced back to the Xhosa word "amalawu" or "ilawu", meaning "Hottentot".

Location or origin: Bangladesh
Targets: Hindus
Meaning, origin and notes: "Malaun" is derived from Bengali মালাউন (maalaaun), which in turn was derived from Arabic "ملعون" (mal'un), which means "cursed" or deprived of God's mercy.

Location or origin: Indonesia
Targets: Malaysian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Used in Indonesia, derived from "maling" (Javanese for "thief") and "Malaysia". It often arises due to perceived instances of Malaysia claiming aspects of Indonesian culture

Location or origin: Indonesia
Targets: Malaysian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Used as the reply to Indon word. Malon is (mostly) a short for "Malaysia Bloon" (dumb Malaysians).

Location or origin: Bulgaria
Targets: Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: From Bulgarian "мангал" (mangal) – a type of pot. Some variants are derived from the similar-sounding loanwords "манго" (mango) – mango and "мангуста" (mangusta) – mongoose.

Location or origin: Finland
Targets: Romani men
Meaning, origin and notes: Possibly from Swedish man or from the name Herman. It refers to Romani men, however can also refer to Romani people generally.

Location or origin: Israel
Targets: Moroccan Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from "Maroko" (Hebrew pronunciation for "Morocco") + "Kaki" (which means "shit", "crap" in Hebrew slang).

Location or origin: Japan
Targets: Chinese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Originally a term used by Unit 731 referring to its human test subjects, Nowadays used by Netto-uyoku sometimes.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: derived from Kenyans of the Kikuyu tribe involved in the Mau Mau Rebellion in the 1950s.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally the Spanish colloquial name of the Figeater beetle.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: White people
Meaning, origin and notes: A term commonly used by black people. A person with a "mayonnaise"-like complexion.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Irish people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Dutch
Targets: Dutch-Moroccan people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Dutch
Targets: German people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: India
Targets: Northeast Indians
Meaning, origin and notes: Used on those that imply they are Chinese foreigners.

Location or origin: Europe
Targets: Usually people of African, Melanesian, or Indigenous Australian descent.
Meaning, origin and notes: A universal slur, meaning it has the same meaning in different languages.

Location or origin: Ukraine, Belarus
Targets: Russians
Meaning, origin and notes: Historically a neutral designation for a person from Muscovy, currently refers to Russians.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: The origin is obscure. May refer to slaves singing at night as crickets chirp as dusk.

Location or origin: Turkey
Targets: Kurdish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Former Turkish governments denied the Kurds their own ethnicity, calling them Mountain Turks (dağ Türkleri). Germans also used this word to describe Albanians, now it refers to the earlier.

Location or origin: Philippines
Targets: Filipino Muslims, notably among Bangsamoro ethnic groups
Meaning, origin and notes: First used by soldiers of the Armed Forces of the Philippines stationed in Mindanao as an ethnic slur towards the Muslim Moro insurgents.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Used by Italian-Americans. Deriving from "mulignana" the word for eggplant in some South Italian linguistic variants. Also called a mouli.

Location or origin: Rhodesia, originally military
Targets: Black people, usually men
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Finland
Targets: Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally "blackling," "blackie," "the black people", when "romani" is the neutral term.

Location or origin: Kosovo
Targets: Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: Expression of contempt for someone, usually Romani people.

Location or origin: Eastern and Southern Africa, Democratic Republic of the Congo
Targets: White people
Meaning, origin and notes: May be both pejorative and affectionate, depending on usage.

Location or origin: Levant
Targets: Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: Arab term for Romani people and other groups sharing an itinerant lifestyle.

Location or origin: Ethiopia/Amharic
Targets: Amhara people
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally means "rifle-bearer", relates to 19th century Ethiopian history. Since 1975, used as inflammatory term by Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF, governing party) officials against Amharas; continued inflammatory/derogatory usage in 2020 online media two years after EPRDF loss of political power.

Location or origin: Slavic languages
Targets: German people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Bengali Hindus
Targets: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: France
Targets: East or Southeast Asian people
Meaning, origin and notes: A corrupted Vietnamese word with similar to "yokel", "country bumpkin", etc.

Location or origin: Negrito
Targets: 
Meaning, origin and notes: Black children

Location or origin: Commonwealth
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Originally used to refer to a novice – a foolish or naive person – before being associated with black people.

Location or origin: International/Worldwide
Targets: Black people, especially African-Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: From the Spanish and Portuguese word negro ("black"), derived from the Latin niger. The Spanish or Portuguese term, or other such languages deriving the term from it such as Filipino, may vary in its connotation per country, where some countries, the connotation may range from either positive, neutral, or negative, depending on context . For example, in Spanish and Portuguese, "negro" may simply refer to the color black. Among Spanish dialects in different countries, it may have either positive or negative connotations, such as describing someone similarly to my darling or my honey in Argentina, or describing someone to be angry in Spain. In Portuguese, the term "negro" is often preferred to the more offensive preto; however, due to the influence of US-American pop culture, the "n-word" can be found in the language as an anglicism, with identical connotations as the English term.

Location or origin: Caribbean
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: To feel sleepy after eating is referred to in and around the Caribbean as having "niggeritis", a direct allusion to the stereotype of laziness of black Africans.

Location or origin: United States, Australia, New Zealand, United Kingdom
Targets: Japanese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Someone of Japanese descent (shortened version of Nipponese, from Japanese name for Japan, Nippon).

Location or origin: Canada
Targets: Native Canadians
Meaning, origin and notes: A Native American (from the Algonquian word for "friend").

Location or origin: Indonesia
Targets: Indonesians of foreign descent, especially Chinese Indonesians
Meaning, origin and notes: The term pribumi was coined after Indonesian independence to replace the derogatory Dutch term Inlander ("native"). "Non-pribumi," often simply "non-pri," was then used to refer to Indonesians of foreign descent and was generally considered to suggest that they were not full citizens. Use of both "pribumi" and "non-pribumi" by government departments was banned by President B.J. Habibie in 1998 according to Inpres (Instruksi Presiden, lit. Presidential Instruction) No. 26 of 1998, along with instruction to stop discrimination by race in government.

Location or origin: United Kingdom
Targets: Northern English people
Meaning, origin and notes: Used in the south of England, relating to the supposed stupidity and lack of sophistication of those in the north of the country. See also Southern Faerie. In some cases, this has been adopted in the north of England, with a pub in Leeds even taking the name "The Northern Monkey".

Location or origin: Syria and the Levant
Targets: Members of the Alawite sect of Shi'a Islam.
Meaning, origin and notes: Once a common and neutral term derived from the name of Ibn Nusayr, the sect's founder, it fell out of favour within the community in the early decades of the 20th century due to the perception that it implied a heretical separateness from mainstream Islam. Resurgent in the context of the ongoing Syrian civil war, the term is now often employed by Sunni fundamentalist enemies of the government of Bashar al-Assad, an Alawite, to suggest that the faith is a human invention lacking divine legitimacy.

Location or origin: African American Vernacular
Targets: White people
Meaning, origin and notes: First recorded in the late 19th century. Origin unknown. Suggestions include Yoruba ófé, "to disappear"; pig Latin for "foe"; and French au fait, "socially proper".

Location or origin: Hungarian-speaking territories
Targets: Romanian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Evolved to a pejorative term, originates from the historical designation of Romanians earlier the 19th century.

Location or origin: Ukraine
Targets: Russian soldiers
Meaning, origin and notes: Orc (Cyrillic: орк, romanised: ork), plural orcs (Russian and Ukrainian: орки, Russian romanisation: orki, Ukrainian: orky), is a pejorative used by Ukrainians to refer to an invading Russian soldier during the Russo-Ukrainian War. It comes from the name of the fictional humanoid monsters of the same name from J. R. R. Tolkien's fantasy novel The Lord of the Rings.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Used as early as the 1960s. Refers to a black person who is perceived as acting white, and therefore black on the outside and white on the inside like an Oreo cookie.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Implying that one or one's ancestors avoided dying in the Holocaust and so avoid the crematorium ovens.

Location or origin: United Kingdom, Isle of Wight
Targets: Mainland United Kingdom Residents
Meaning, origin and notes: A term used by residents of the Isle of Wight, sometimes pejoratively, to refer to people from the mainland United Kingdom.

Location or origin: United Kingdom
Targets: Irish people

Location or origin: Australia

Boong, pronounced with ʊ (like the vowel in bull), is related to the Australian English slang word bung, meaning "dead", "infected", or "dysfunctional". From bung, to go bung "Originally to die, then to break down, go bankrupt, cease to function [Ab. bong dead]". The 1988 edition of the Australian National Dictionary gives its origin in the Wemba word for "man" or "human being". However, Frederick Ludowyk of the Australian National Dictionary Centre wrote in 2004 that bong meaning "dead" is not a Wiradjuri word, but may have been picked up or assumed from the word "bung" which was originally a Yagara word which was used in the pidgin widely spoken across Australia in colonial times.

Ironically, there was no relevant immigration of ethnic Turks to Brazil.

However, most likely it's due to the fact that during World War One there was a trade embargo in place during Gallipoli, but Llanelli continued to trade tin with the Turkish; this led to people from neighbouring Swansea and other surrounding areas referring to them as Turks.

The usage of the word "żyd" in Polish depends on capitalisation and grammatical form: upper-case Żyd is neutral and denotes Jews in general or Jews as a nationality; the lower-case form (żyd, plural: żydzi) denotes a follower of Judaism; both are neutral. Related terms are considered offensive: alternative plural "żydy" or diminutive "żydek" (plural: żydki).

Location or origin: USSR (from late 1950s)
Targets: Children of mixed ancestry, usually with a father who is black or (more rarely) other non-European origins
Meaning, origin and notes: It is believed that the first noticeable appearance of black and or mixed ancestry children appeared after the 6th World Festival of Youth and Students of 1957. The term was often used ironically and sometimes in a mildly derogatory fashion. This term is currently not used.

Location or origin: France
Targets: Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: East Germany
Targets: East or Southeast Asian people, particularly Vietnamese people
Meaning, origin and notes: German for Fiji, used to refer to anyone who looks East or Southeast Asian, particularly those of Vietnamese origin.

Location or origin: Denmark
Targets: Norwegian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Means mountain ape. Jocularly used by Danes mostly in sports. From the 1950s. Norway is mountainous while Denmark is flat without mountains.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Filipino people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Chile
Targets: French people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Ashkenazi Jews
Targets: Sephardi and Mizrahi Jews
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from Franks (as a reference to Western Europeans), due to the fact Sephardi Jews are Judaeo-Spanish speakers.

Location or origin: United Kingdom, France, Hungary, Poland, Russia, Latvia
Targets: German people
Meaning, origin and notes: from Friedrich (Frederick).

Location or origin: Australia, Canada, United Kingdom, United States, Germany
Targets: Dutch people (formerly) French and French Canadian people (currently)
Meaning, origin and notes: Before the 19th century, referred to the Dutch (as they were stereotyped as being marsh-dwellers). When France became Britain's main enemy, replacing the Dutch, the epithet was transferred to them, because of the French penchant for eating frogs' legs (see comparable French term Rosbif). Also known in Slavic countries, but only towards the (mainland) French, see Polish żabojad, Ukrainian zhaboyid (жабоїд), Russian lyagushatnik (лягушатник); as well as in Basque frantximant.

Location or origin: United Kingdom
Targets: Hadendoa people
Meaning, origin and notes: Term used to refer to the Hadendoa warriors in the 19th century, in reference to their elaborate hairstyles. Not applicable in Australia, see Fuzzy Wuzzy Angels.

Location or origin: Spain, Chile
Targets: French people
Meaning, origin and notes: From Occitan gavach meaning "one who speaks wrong."

Location or origin: Mexico
Targets: American people, French people
Meaning, origin and notes: Neutral or pejorative depending on context.

Location or origin: Albania, Kosovo
Targets: Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: Expression of disdain for someone, with the setting "Maxhup"

Location or origin: 
Targets: Non-Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: Technically a term for a person who does not possess Romanipen, it usually refers to non-Romanis and Romanis who do not live within Romani culture.

Location or origin: Japan
Targets: Foreigners, espesically those of non-East Asian origin
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Ethiopia
Targets: Oromo people or others in Ethiopia and Somalia
Meaning, origin and notes: Used since 1670

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: Cape Coloured or Coloured people
Meaning, origin and notes: It means "a person who is low or of inferior status" in Afrikaans.

Location or origin: USSR
Targets: German people, or more uncommonly Latvian people
Meaning, origin and notes: The term originated among the Soviet troops in World War II, coming from Russified form of the German first name Hans.

Location or origin: Romania
Targets: Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: It means crow.

Location or origin: South Korea
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Korean for coon

Location or origin: Kosovo
Targets: Serbs of Šumadija
Meaning, origin and notes: Derogatory expression for the Serbs of southern Serbia, of Šumadija.

Location or origin: Australia
Targets: Aboriginal woman
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: Australia
Targets: White people
Meaning, origin and notes: A white person having casual sex with an Aboriginal woman.

Location or origin: France
Targets: English people
Meaning, origin and notes: An antiquated pejorative expression. Possibly a corruption of "God-damn".

Location or origin: United States, Australia, United Kingdom, New Zealand
Targets: Darkskinned people, especially African-Caribbeans
Meaning, origin and notes: An expression which originally was a children's literature character and type of black doll but which eventually came to be used as a jibe against people with dark skin.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: East and Southeast Asians, but particularly Koreans
Meaning, origin and notes: The earliest recorded example is dated 1920. Used especially for enemy soldiers. Its use has been traced to United States Marines serving in the Philippines in the early 20th century. It gained widespread notice as a result of the Korean and Vietnam wars.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Italian people, Italian-Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: Initially applied to Italian or Italian-American men in general, it now also specifically carries connotations of stereotypical vulgar machismo and Italian Mafia or Italian-American Mafia involvement among ethnic Italians and Italian-Americans. However, "goombah" is also used among Italian-Americans themselves to refer to a friend or comrade; the word becomes pejorative mostly when used by a non-Italian to refer to an ethnic Italian or Italian-American in a derogatory or patronizing way rather than as a friendly term of address among Italian-Americans. Originates from the Southern Italian word cumpa or cumpari and the Standard Italian equivalent, compare, meaning "godfather".

Location or origin: India
Targets: Europeans and other light-skinned people
Meaning, origin and notes: The word gorā simply means "fair-skinned" in Hindi and other Indo-Aryan languages, derived from Sanskrit gaura (गौर "white, shining"). However, it has recently been used as a racial epithet for White people. "Gori" is the feminine form.

Location or origin: Hebrew
Targets: Non-Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: A Hebrew biblical term for "Nation" or "People". By Roman times it had also acquired the meaning of "non-Jew". In English, use may be benign, to refer to anyone who isn't Jewish, or controversial, as it can have pejorative connotations.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Eurasians, Kristang people
Meaning, origin and notes: A term for Eurasians, and specifically for the Kristang people of Malaysia, many of whom were traditionally engaged in shrimp fishing. It often has pejorative connotations, especially when used by outsiders, though in recent generations members of the community have to some degree tried to reclaim the term.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Mediterranean/Southern European and Hispanic people, and especially Italian people.
Meaning, origin and notes: Greaseball often generally refers to Italians or a person of Italian descent. Meanwhile, though it may be used as a shortening of greaseball to refer to Italians, greaser has been more often applied to Hispanic Americans or Mexican Americans. However, greaseball (and to a lesser extent, greaser) can also refer to any person of Mediterranean/Southern European descent or Hispanic descent, including Greeks, Spaniards, and the Portuguese, as well as Latin Americans. Greaser also refer to members of a 1950-1960s subculture which Italian Americans and Hispanic Americans were stereotyped to be a part of. "Greaser" in reference to the subculture has taken on a less derogatory connotation since the 1950s.

Location or origin: United States, New England region, especially Massachusetts.
Targets: Portuguese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Can also be used in a non-derogatory context when not referring to the Portuguese to mean anyone inexperienced at something.

Location or origin: Spanish speakers, mostly Latin America
Targets: English speakers
Meaning, origin and notes: Sometimes used by Latino Americans. In Mexico, the term means an American. Likely from the Spanish word "griego", meaning Greek (similar to the English expression "It's all Greek to me").

Location or origin: Brazil
Targets: Foreigners
Meaning, origin and notes: A colloquial neutral term for any foreigner, regardless of race, ethnicity or origin (including Portuguese people), or for a person whose native language is not Portuguese (including people whose native language is Spanish).

Location or origin: Southern Brazil
Targets: Italian descendants
Meaning, origin and notes: A colloquial neutral term for Italian descendants of southern Brazil, specially in Rio Grande do Sul

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from "negroid".

Location or origin: Australia
Targets: White people
Meaning, origin and notes: Aboriginal term for white people

Location or origin: Mainland China
Targets: Non-Chinese
Meaning, origin and notes: Basically the same meaning as the term gweilo used in Hong Kong. More often used when referring foreigners as military enemies, such as riben guizi (日本鬼子, Japanese devils, because of Second Sino-Japanese War), meiguo guizi (美国鬼子, American devils, because of Korean War).

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Italian Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: Derives from the Italian given name, Guido. Guidette is the female counterpart. Used mostly in the Northeastern United States as a stereotype for working-class urban Italian Americans.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Italian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Most likely derived from "Guinea Negro", implying that Italians are dark or swarthy-skinned like the natives of Guinea. The diminutive "Ginzo" probably dates back to World War II and is derived from Australian slang picked up by United States servicemen in the Pacific Theater.

Location or origin: Switzerland
Targets: German people
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally "rubber neck"

Location or origin: Cuba
Targets: Cuban exiles after the revolution
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally "worm"

Location or origin: Southern Mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau
Targets: White men
Meaning, origin and notes: Loosely translated as "foreign devil"; more literally, might be "ghost dude/bloke/guy/etc". Gwei means "ghost". The color white is associated with ghosts in China. A lo is a regular guy (i.e. a fellow, a chap, or a bloke). Once a mark of xenophobia, the word is now in general, informal use.

Location or origin: North Africa
Targets: White people
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: 
Targets: Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: Shortened version of "gypsy"

Location or origin: Korea
Targets: Estranged Korean people
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally "sojourner". A Korean who was born or raised overseas, particularly the United States. (see also banana in this page)

Location or origin: United Kingdom, Australia
Targets: Egyptian people and Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from "Egyptian", Egypt being mistakenly considered these people's origin.

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: Afrikaners
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: United States Military
Targets: Iraqi people
Meaning, origin and notes: May also be used to describe anyone from a predominantly Muslim country. Derived from the honorific Al-Hajji, the title given to a Muslim who has completed the Hajj (pilgrimage to Mecca).

Location or origin: 
Targets: Multi-ethnic people
Meaning, origin and notes: Métis is a French term, also used in Canadian English, for a half-breed, and mestizo is the equivalent in Spanish, although these are not offensive per se.

Location or origin: England, Australia
Targets: Mixed race (usually between Australian Aboriginal and white people in Australian parlance)
Meaning, origin and notes: Originally used as a legal and social term.

Location or origin: United States, Hawaiian
Targets: Non-Hawaiian people, almost always white people.
Meaning, origin and notes: Can be used neutrally, dependent on context.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from the word "Hebrew."

Location or origin: China, Taiwan
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally means "black ghost" or "black devil", used similarly to English phrases such as nigga or nigger.

Location or origin: South Korea
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Korean: Black brother. A Korean ethnic slur sometimes for black people.

Location or origin: Finland
Targets: Romani people
Meaning, origin and notes: From hevos- + mies, referring to Gypsy horsemanship.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Italian immigrants
Meaning, origin and notes: Sometimes used with or to distinguish from "Hunk" ("Hunky").

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Appalachian or Ozark Americans
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location or origin: United States
Targets: White people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from an African American pronunciation of "hunky," the disparaging term for a Hungarian laborer. The first record of its use as an insulting term for a white person dates from the 1950s.

Location or origin: New Zealand
Targets: European New Zealanders
Meaning, origin and notes: Used by Māori to refer to New Zealanders of European descent.

Location or origin: New Zealand
Targets: Māori
Meaning, origin and notes: From the formerly common Maorified version of the English name George.

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: Khoisans and Cape Coloureds or Coloureds
Meaning, origin and notes: A derogatory term historically used to refer to the Khoisan people of Southern Africa and their descendants, coloureds. It originated from the Dutch settlers who arrived in the region in the 17th century.

Location or origin: South Africa
Targets: Black people
Meaning, origin and notes: Literally "wooden head"

Location or origin: Taiwan and Southeast Asia
Targets: Non-Chinese native people
Meaning, origin and notes: This word is derogatory because huan-a means "foreigner" which portrays non-Chinese natives as not human[citation needed]. In Taiwan, it carries the connotation of "aborigine". In Indonesia, it refers to non-Chinese native people descended from the many ethnolinguistic groups native to Indonesia commonly known by the term pribumi (e.g., Javanese, Sundanese, Batak, and Buginese).

Location or origin: Argentina, Chile
Targets: Non-Mapuche Chileans, non-Mapuche Argentines
Meaning, origin and notes: Mapuche term dating back at least to the Conquest of Chile.

Location or origin: Mongolia
Targets: Chinese people
Meaning, origin and notes: Equivalent to the word chink.

Location or origin: United States, United Kingdom
Targets: German people
Meaning, origin and notes: (United States, United Kingdom) Germans, especially German soldiers; popular during World War I. Derived from a speech given by Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany to the German contingent sent to China during the Boxer Rebellion in which he exhorted them to "be like Huns" (i.e., savage and ruthless) to their Chinese enemy.

Location or origin: Ireland
Targets: Protestants and British soldiers
Meaning, origin and notes: A Protestant in Northern Ireland or historically, a member of the British military in Ireland ("Britannia's huns").

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Central European laborers.
Meaning, origin and notes: It originated in the coal regions of Pennsylvania and West Virginia, where Poles and other immigrants from Central Europe (Hungarians (Magyar), Rusyns, Slovaks) came to perform hard manual labor in the mines.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from the personal name Hyman (from the Hebrew name Chayyim). Jesse Jackson provoked controversy when he referred to New York City as "Hymietown" in 1984. Has also been spelled "Heimie", as a reflection of popular Jewish last names ending in -heim.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from the name Isaac, an important figure in Hebrew culture.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from the name Isaac, an important figure in Hebrew culture.

Location or origin: 
Targets: Jewish people
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from the names Isaac and Moses, two important figures in Hebrew culture.

Location or origin: Malaysia, Singapore
Targets: Indonesian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Clipping of Indonesia.

Location or origin: Malaysia
Targets: Indonesian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Which similar to "Indon" term mixed with "Dog" and "Sial" (Malay word for "Damn").

Location or origin: Philippines
Targets: Chinese Filipino people
Meaning, origin and notes: Used in Filipino/Tagalog and other Philippine languages. Based on the Philippine Hokkien term, Chinese: 𪜶 叔; Pe̍h-ōe-jī: in chek; lit. 'his/her/their uncle'.

Location or origin: Rwanda
Targets: Tutsi people
Meaning, origin and notes: A person of the Tutsi ethnic group in Africa. Literally means "Cockroach" and reportedly derives from how Tutsi rebels would attack at night and retreat, being hard to kill, like a cockroach. Most notably came to worldwide prominence around the time of the Rwanda genocide, as it was used by the RTLM in order to incite genocide.

Location or origin: United States
Targets: Native Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: Corruption of "Indian"

Location or origin: Germany
Targets: Italian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Formerly used as a nickname for Italian soldiers and the since the 1960s as a slur for Italian immigrants.

Religious slurs.description: List of religious slurs according to wiki with description. Similar to the ethnic ones, contains several normally harmless terms, which I left in because it might still trigger censorship filters or badly designed MR algos.

terms.description:
Location of origin: North America
Targeted demographic: Pentecostals
Meaning, origin and notes: A dysphemism for people who believe in the fundamentalist authority of the Bible, particularly those from a Pentecostal or fundamentalist denomination. It is also a slang term for an evangelising Christian. Commonly used universally against Christians who are perceived to go out of their way to energetically preach their faith to others.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Christian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Someone perceived as aggressively imposing their Christian beliefs upon others. The term derives from preachers thumping their hands down on the Bible, or thumping the Bible itself, to emphasize a point during a sermon. The term's target domain is broad and can often extend to anyone engaged in a public show of religion, fundamentalist or not. The term is frequently used in English-speaking countries.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Selection of Christian doctrines
Meaning, origin and notes: Used by some Christians, and others, to accuse other Christian individuals or denominations of selecting which Christian doctrines they will follow, and which they will not.

Location of origin: Punjab, Pakistan
Targeted demographic: Lower-class Christians and menial workers; later used against Christians in general. Also used against Pakistani Hindu people.
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from the name of the Chuhra caste, historically a Dalit caste whose traditional occupation was sweeping and cleaning. Most Christians in Punjab are from this community, and still they are the majority of street sweepers in Punjab province. The term became an abuse for all Christians.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Christian fundamentalists
Meaning, origin and notes: Shortening of fundamentalist. Usually used to mean a Christian fundamentalist.

Location of origin: Australia
Targeted demographic: Christian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Similar to Bible basher, a person who is very vocal about their religion and prayer.

Location of origin: Pakistan
Targeted demographic: Christian people
Meaning, origin and notes: From Isa, the name of Jesus Christ from the Qur'an as a prophet of Islam. The term literally means '[person/people] of Jesus', but it later meant 'street sweeper' or 'labourer'.

Location of origin: United Kingdom, India
Targeted demographic: Materially benefiting Christians In India: Christians (especially lower caste converts)
Meaning, origin and notes: Someone who has formally declared themself a Christian for material benefits rather than for religious reasons. In India, the term has been extended to refer to any Christian convert.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Scientologists
Meaning, origin and notes: Referring to a passage about clam engrams in L. Ron Hubbard's 1952 book, What To Audit, later renamed Scientology: A History of Man.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Vodouists, African diaspora people, particularly Haitian Americans
Meaning, origin and notes: Used against people practicing any indigenous African religions to imply they are fraudulent and dangerous, with racialized connotations of curses and primitive superstitions. Used to justify Afrophobic legislation.

Location of origin: Jamaica
Targeted demographic: Practitioners of Obeah, Black Jamaicans
Meaning, origin and notes: Used against practicioners of Obeah as well as people who receive services from Obeah priests. Connotation of being fraudulent, deceptive, vengeful, and uncivilized. Originally used by colonial authorities to suppress slave rebellions that were organized by Obeah spiritual leaders. Laws still exist in Jamaica criminalizing Obeah.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Followers of Church of Christ
Meaning, origin and notes: Followers of the Church of Christ, from American Restoration Movement leaders Thomas Campbell and Alexander Campbell, the latter being one of two key people considered the founders of the movement.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Pentecostal and Charismatic Christians
Meaning, origin and notes: Named after Church services involving rolling on the floor in an uncontrolled manner.

Location of origin: United Kingdom, Ireland
Targeted demographic: Christian Protestants, especially Glasgow Rangers supporters
Meaning, origin and notes: Used by Irish republicans against Protestant unionists, especially by Glasgow Celtic supporters against those of Glasgow Rangers

Location of origin: United Kingdom
Targeted demographic: Christian Protestants
Meaning, origin and notes: Named after a common orange-flavoured cake/biscuit in Ireland and UK.

Location of origin: United Kingdom, Ireland
Targeted demographic: Christian Protestants
Meaning, origin and notes: Particularly used by bullies to disparage a child who attends a Protestant school. Proddywhoddy and proddywoddy are used in children's school rhymes in Cork.

Location of origin: Ireland
Targeted demographic: Ulster Protestants
Meaning, origin and notes: Referring to the Orange Order

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Jehovah's Witnesses
Meaning, origin and notes: Jehovah's Witnesses, from American religious leader Charles Taze Russell.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Christian people
Meaning, origin and notes: Member of the United Society of Believers in Christ's Second Appearing. Originated as "Shaking Quakers", in reference to their similarity to Quakers as well as their charismatic worship practices, which involved dancing, shouting, and speaking in tongues. The term was originally derogatory, but very early on was embraced and used by the Shakers themselves.

Location of origin: Ireland
Targeted demographic: Christian who has sold out their beliefs
Meaning, origin and notes: Person who has sold out their beliefs, referring to the Great Famine of Ireland when some Catholics converted to a Protestant faith in order to gain access to a free meal.

Location of origin: United Kingdom
Targeted demographic: Roman Catholics
Meaning, origin and notes: An informal phrase for a Roman Catholic, particularly in the armed forces. Derived from a belief that Irish laborers kick their shovels into the ground with their left foot.

Location of origin: United Kingdom
Targeted demographic: Irish Catholics
Meaning, origin and notes: A term originally referencing the Fenian Brotherhood and the Irish Republican Brotherhood, organizations which supported a united Ireland. Today the term is used as a sectarian slur by Protestants, especially in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Australia.

Location of origin: North America
Targeted demographic: Roman Catholics
Meaning, origin and notes: The term originated in the U.S. in the 1850s and refers to the custom of Friday abstinence. The Friday abstinence from meat (red meat and poultry) distinguishes Catholics from other Christians, especially in North America.

Location of origin: United Kingdom
Targeted demographic: Irish Catholic
Meaning, origin and notes: Usually an Irish Catholic (a reference to the common "Mc" patronymic of Irish surnames, or a hypocorism of "Michael").

Location of origin: Northern Ireland, North America
Targeted demographic: Roman Catholic
Meaning, origin and notes: Usually Irish Catholic; online often used generically for any Catholic.

Location of origin: North America
Targeted demographic: Roman Catholics
Meaning, origin and notes: A name given to Catholics for their keeping so many holy days - marked in their almanacs with red-coloured letters.

Location of origin: Ireland
Targeted demographic: Roman Catholics
Meaning, origin and notes: Roman Catholic person, now considered archaic due to its association with the better-known American term.

Location of origin: England
Targeted demographic: Roman Catholics
Meaning, origin and notes: Term used when anti-Catholicism was more common in the United States, as well as in Northern Ireland by Ulster Protestants

Location of origin: Unknown
Targeted demographic: Roman Catholics
Meaning, origin and notes: Usually disparaging: a tonsured clergyman, priest.

Location of origin: Northern Ireland
Targeted demographic: Irish Catholics
Meaning, origin and notes: From tadhg, Irish for "Timothy".

Location of origin: 
Targeted demographic: Syriac Orthodox
Meaning, origin and notes: The term is named after Jacob Baradeus who liberated the Oriental Orthodox from persecution in the mid-6th century. This title is rejected by the Syriac Orthodox as it assumes that the Church had been started by Jacob.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Latter Day Saint
Meaning, origin and notes: Term for the stereotype of a "perfect" female member of LDS Church.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Latter Day Saint
Meaning, origin and notes: Term for the stereotype of a "perfect" male member of LDS Church.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Latter Day Saint
Meaning, origin and notes: A non-faithful LDS person or a non-Mormon altogether. Jack Mormon is usually used by non-Mormons to describe Mormons that do not follow the Word of Wisdom (dietary and health practices that exclude the use of tobacco or alcohol) and by Mormons to describe members that do not sufficiently follow practices. It is also used by Mormons to describe those who were Mormon but remain friendly to the church. It may be applied to ex-Mormons who have repudiated the church and its teachings but that is a rare usage.

Location of origin: India
Targeted demographic: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Derives from the common Muslim name Abdul.

Location of origin: India
Targeted demographic: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Portmanteau of the words Chutiya+Muslim, chutiya being a common swear word in Hindi/Urdu.

Location of origin: India
Targeted demographic: Muslims, especially fundamentalist Jihadists
Meaning, origin and notes: Derives from jihad.

Location of origin: Indonesia
Targeted demographic: Islamic fundamentalism and reactionaries
Meaning, origin and notes: Portmanteau of kadal gurun meaning 'desert lizard'. Originated as a social media political insult, the term is used for closed-minded Muslims influenced by Islamic extremism and fundamentalism from the Middle East.

Location of origin: Myanmar
Targeted demographic: Rohingyas, Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Term meaning 'black' in various Indo-Aryan languages, referring to the dark skin colour of South Asian Muslims. The term originally was targeted at all Muslims of South Asia, but more recently is used as a slur directly against Rohingyas due to their perceived Bangladeshi origin.

Location of origin: India
Targeted demographic: Muslim men
Meaning, origin and notes: Derives from the Hindi/Urdu for 'cut' referring to circumcision, a common practice among Muslim men.

Location of origin: Assam, India
Targeted demographic: Bengali Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Derives from the honorific Mian.

Location of origin: India
Targeted demographic: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Derives from mullah, a common title for Islamic religious scholars.

Location of origin: Philippines
Targeted demographic: Filipino Muslims (especially among Bangsamoro ethnic groups)
Meaning, origin and notes: First used by soldiers of the Armed Forces of the Philippines stationed in Mindanao as an ethnic slur towards the Muslim Moro insurgents.

Location of origin: Australia
Targeted demographic: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: A shortened version of the word Muslim.

Location of origin: India
Targeted demographic: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Derives from namaz, the Persian word for obligatory daily prayers usually used instead of salah in the Indian subcontinent.

Location of origin: India
Targeted demographic: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Derives from the common statement that Islam is a "religion of peace". Sometimes the Hindi word "shantidoot" (Messenger of Peace) is used.

Location of origin: North America
Targeted demographic: Islamic men
Meaning, origin and notes: From Osama bin Laden.

Location of origin: Pakistan
Targeted demographic: Ahmadiyya
Meaning, origin and notes: The term originates from Qadian, a small town in present-day Indian Punjab, the birthplace of Mirza Ghulam Ahmad, the founder of the Ahmadiyya movement. The use of Qadiani is primarily in Pakistan. The term has even been used in official Pakistani documents. It is also known as the Q-word.

Location of origin: Arab peninsula
Targeted demographic: Shīʿi Muslims (regardless of race)
Meaning, origin and notes: Term originally denoting extremist Shīʿites who reject (rafḍ) the caliphates of Abu Bakr and ʿUmar; often employed by critics as a slur against those Shīʿi Muslims who do not criticize the first three Caliphs, but only believe in "Alī’s right to the caliphate over Muʿāwiyah".

Location of origin: North America
Targeted demographic: Islamic turban wearers
Meaning, origin and notes: From Islamic wearing of turbans.

Location of origin: Iraq
Targeted demographic: Feyli Kurds
Meaning, origin and notes: Mainly used by higher class Sunni Arabs during Ba'athist Iraq to insult Feyli Kurds for their belief in Shia Islam

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Used by radical anti-Islamists, due to anti-Muslim sentiments following September 11 attacks and subsequently ISIS attacks.

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Muslims
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from the honorific Al-Hajji, the title given to a Muslim who has completed the Hajj (pilgrimage to Mecca).

Location of origin: Western countries
Targeted demographic: Hindus
Meaning, origin and notes: Referring to the practice of drinking gomutra, or cow urine, as a folk medicine advocated by some Hindu groups.

Location of origin: Western countries
Targeted demographic: Hindus, especially women
Meaning, origin and notes: Referring to the practice of applying bindis, a dot-like marking used by married women. Also the namesake of a terrorist group from New Jersey that murdered Indians known as the Dotbusters.

Location of origin: Bangladesh
Targeted demographic: Hindus, especially those from Bangladesh
Meaning, origin and notes: Derived from Bengali মালাউন (maalaaun), which in turn was derived from Arabic ملعون (mal'un), which means 'cursed' or deprived from God's mercy.

Location of origin: India, Pakistan
Targeted demographic: Sikhs
Meaning, origin and notes: In reference to the famous Punjabi beverage Lassi which is a term used to denigrate Sikhs and Punjabis in general. This slur is mostly used by people from the Bihar region

Location of origin: India, Pakistan
Targeted demographic: Gursikhs
Meaning, origin and notes:

Location of origin: United States
Targeted demographic: Sikh turban wearers
